awd_titl_txt: Enantioenriched Silanol and Siloxy Compounds as Catalysts and Ligands
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Annaliese Franz in the Department of Chemistry at the University of California, Davis. Professor Franz is developing new silicon-based molecules and using them to prepare structurally-defined complexes with metals. These complexes are being studied as catalysts for applications such as the efficient synthesis of organic materials and renewable polymers that are used in technology, medicine, and daily life. The use of catalysts is important for increasing industrial efficiency in advanced manufacturing and reducing waste production.  Silicon is the second most abundant element in the earth's crust, as such this research is addressing issues of sustainability.  This project also
contributes to training the next generation of scientists and broadening participation. Dr. Franz engages in mentoring and outreach activities to broaden participation in STEM, including demonstrations and workshops for 7th and 8th grade girls with AAUW TechTrek and STEM for Girls. She also designs and implements a First-year Seminar - CURE (Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience) - to engage a diverse group of first-year and transfer students with hands-on research opportunities to build critical skills that will help launch them into careers in science and technology.

This project aims to develop new metal-siloxide complexes with high catalytic activity and selectivity for the synthesis of chiral molecules. The design and synthesis of four new classes of chiral siloxy compounds is being investigated to prepare chiral ligands. Using these newly designed silanol ligands, a series of novel metal-siloxide complexes is being prepared where the metal-coordinating abilities, structural studies, stability, and catalytic activity are examined. The structure, binding interactions, and mechanism of the new catalysts are being studied using various spectroscopy methods, kinetics, X-ray crystallography, and mass spectrometry. This project is also training undergraduate and graduate students to develop technical and critical thinking skills for chemical synthesis and catalysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project has studied and developed new silicon-containing molecules, methods and catalysts for applications to the efficient synthesis of organic materials used in technology, medicine, and daily life, with the focus of increasing sustainability and reducing waste production. Silicon is the 2nd most abundant element in the earth’s crust and can be incorporated into organic molecules, yet the synthetic methods are much less developed compared to carbon analogs.  This is especially true for the selective synthesis of silicon-containing molecules in their chiral (stereogenic) form, where only one 3-dimensional shape (stereochemistry) of the molecule is produced based on the groups attached to the silicon atom. 

 

As an outcome of this research, we have demonstrated two new methods for producing chiral silicon molecules based on the 3-dimensional shape of the groups on the silicon atoms – in each case, reacting with a single bond to break the symmetry of a symmetrical molecule. One method has been developed using a metal catalyst to selectively activate a single silicon-hydrogen bond in a symmetrical molecule, and a second method has been developed using a non-metal organocatalyst to protect half of the symmetrical molecule so that the other group selectively reacts. Both cases selectively react to a produce unique 3-dimensional shapes of the desired molecule.  For both methods and catalysts, we have used high level spectroscopy techniques to study the molecular interactions and structural features to determine the factors that allow these new reactions to be performed selectively.  Elaborating on this work, as an additional outcome of this research, the same catalyst and silicon-hydrogen bond activation method was developed and applied for the first time to produce new organic-silicon-hybrid nanomaterials.

 

As an outcome of this research, we have also created new silicon-containing molecules in their chiral form, where only one 3-dimensional shape (stereochemistry) of the silicon-containing molecule is produced based on the different groups attached to an adjacent carbon atom.  These new chiral silicon-containing molecules have been demonstrated as new ligands for chiral metal catalysts, with applications for the activation of nitrogen-hydrogen bonds for selective synthesis of chiral organic molecules used as building blocks in materials and medicine.  The molecular interactions and structural features for the new ligand and catalyst were also studied using high level spectroscopy techniques to determine the factors that allow the reaction to be performed selectively using the new silicon-containing ligands.  

 

All of this work has contributed to training undergraduate and graduate students to develop technical, communication and critical thinking skills as the next generation of scientists and for broadening participation for research and educational goals. The PI engaged in mentoring and outreach activities to broaden participation in STEM, including demonstrations and workshops for elementary and middle school girls to participate in hands-on activities and learn about catalysts, energy, and polymers. 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/01/2024
Modified by: Annaliese K Franz
